awd_titl_txt: Firebug: A Living Cell that Propagates Plasmids Built from an Artificial Genetic System
awd_abstract_narration:
Our view of life is very much influenced by the life on Earth around us.  All of the life on Earth (that we know of) descends from a single common ancestor, and it all has fundamentally the same biochemistry.  This means that our view of biology is very much biased, reflecting only what we know of our surrounding biosphere and ourselves.  The scientific goal of this project is to expand this view, something important to understand the intimate connection between the phenomenon that we know as life and the molecules that underlie it.  This expanded view will be important, for example, should we encounter alien life in our search of the cosmos.  It is equally important if we wish to use life-like processes in commerce, manufacturing, and medicine.  The "grand challenge" to be met by this project is to create a cell that is able to use an entirely synthetic form of DNA; one built from 6 nucleotide "letters", which is two more than the number of nucleotides found in natural DNA.  In pursuing this challenge, more will be learned about the chemistry of metabolism, reproduction, and genetic regulation.  In addition to its scientific interest as a second example of a genetic system able to evolve, the cell will also have practical value.  This cell will be used to manufacture molecules for human and animal diagnostics, for homeland security, and for manufacturing as a bio safe platform.  Undergraduate students will participate in the research activities, and the findings will continue to provide useful insights and perspectives on the origins of life and the nature of extraterrestrial life.  This project is co-funded by the Systems and Synthetic Biology Cluster within the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Chemistry of Life Processes in the Chemistry Division.

This project will engineer a strain of E. coli ("Firebug") that can propagate plasmid DNA carrying nucleotides from a "second-generation" artificially expanded genetic information system (AEGIS).  In its broadest form, AEGIS increases the number of independently replicable nucleotides in DNA from 4 to 12.  This project will begin by adding just two AEGIS components, named (Z and P), to the four natural nucleotides (GACT), exploiting prior work that has (1) optimized second-generation AEGIS components for their chemical and enzymatic performance; (2) developed in vitro molecular biology to support AEGIS DNA, including six-letter GACTZP PCR, sequencing, and endonucleases, ligases, and kinases that use GACTZP DNA; (3) demonstrated in vitro evolution of GACTZP DNA, including generation of aptamers by evolution in the laboratory; and (4) engineered kinases that convert dZ and dP to their triphosphates inside cells.  To pass the next milestone in synthetic biology that makes the expanded code functional in the cell, Firebug will be constructed.  This will involve managing E. coli's error-prone polymerases and repair systems, moving enzymes encoding biosynthesis of Z and P into the chromosome, and placing the engineered cells under selection to improve their fidelity of replication of plasmid-borne Z:P pairs.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project was to modify E. coli so that it is able to maintain genetic material that is augmented with extra “letters”. These extra letters come in the form of artificial base pairs that preferentially hybridize to themselves while avoiding cross-hybridization with natural base pairs. The addition of artificial base pairs to DNA increases its information content and begins a new era of synthetic biology, with many applications in diagnostics and biotechnology.

To manage a project of this complexity we divided the work into three areas of focus:

1.)    Develop a biosynthetic pathway to convert artificial substrates into the precursors necessary for incorporation by enzymes into DNA.

2.)    Understand how the enzymes that make DNA (polymerases) interact with and utilize the artificial substrates.

3.)    Study how the living system responds to the artificial precursors and DNA containing extra letters.

The first goal began with the development of new techniques to measure conversion of artificial DNA precursors (nucleosides) into activated forms. This activation step is carried out by kinases, which attach phosphates to the nucleosides. Full activation of the nucleoside precursors requires addition of three phosphates in three sequential steps. For the first phosphorylation step, we were able to engineer a mutation into a kinase from fruit fly that allowed the utilization of artificial nucleosides more effectively. For the second phosphorylation we have found kinases from thermophilic bacteria able to add the second phosphate slowly, but need improvement through further engineering. For the third phosphorylation we found that kinases already present in E. coli can readily convert the artificial substrate to the final form, ready for incorporation into DNA. Thus, we are very close to completing the biosynthetic pathway.

The second goal, studying incorporation of artificial base pairs into DNA, again required development of new techniques to measure incorporation of the artificial nucleoside triphosphates into templates synthesized to contain matching artificial base-pairs. By modifying an existing fluorescence-based assay we were able to adapt it to screen polymerases for their ability to incorporate the proper artificial base pair while also determining how often mispair (polymerase pair a natural base with an artificial one) errors occurred. With this assay, we were able to determine how accurately polymerase from the bacterial host would copy the artificial DNA, while also testing enzyme variants for improved accuracy. In addition, we assayed polymerases from different organisms and found several that can synthesize DNA with artificial base-pairs fairly accurately, giving us multiple enzymes to use in our system.

To study how a living system responds to DNA with extra letters we simply inserted this DNA into E. coli in the form of a circular plasmid DNA. Bacteria that do not have the biosynthetic pathway to make artificial DNA are forced to either delete the foreign DNA or misincorporate natural bases to pair with the artificial ones. We found that E. coli do not delete the artificial DNA, they write over it in a sequence-specific manner. Therefore, for a given starting sequence of artificial bases, we can predict how it will be replaced by natural DNA. This allows us to monitor the maintenance of the unnatural DNA in living hosts that can make the necessary artificial precursors.

All organisms have evolved DNA repair systems to fix the normal mistakes from polymerases during the copying of DNA and chemical damage to the DNA (e.g. UV or mutagenic chemicals). When our bacterial host receives DNA containing extra letters, these DNA repair systems may view this new DNA as damage needing repair. As a start to what will be a long and hopefully revealing study of how natural systems manage new base pairs, we isolated the major mis-match sensing protein from E. coli and tested its interactions with properly paired natural and artificial DNA, in contrast to DNA containing mis-pairs of both. This mis-match sensing protein binds to DNA that have distortions caused when bases cannot properly pair. We found that the mis-match detection protein does not bind to properly paired artificial DNA, indicating that this augmented DNA assumes the same geometry as natural DNA and does not appear as damage. When natural DNA is mis-paired with artificial DNA, this repair protein interacts with the structures as it does with mis-pairs of natural DNA. This indicates that at least this DNA repair system will help maintain artificial DNA in the host bacteria when natural DNA is erroneously incorporated across from artificial.

These outcomes show that natural systems can tolerate and even work with an artificially expanded genetic information system, and bring us much closer to a new era in synthetic biology.
